title: What is the largest mountain in the world? - Quora

response.answer_text: The intriguing aspect of this question is the many ways it can be answered depending on the definition of the key word “largest”: Highest from sea level: Mount Everest (29,000, base is at 17,800).Highest from land base to peak: Denali (Mt. McKinley). (20,210, base is at 7,200)Furthest from the Center of the Earth/ Closest to the Sun: Chimborazo 25,600. It’s near the equator, which bulges out farther than the latitude of Everest because Earth is an oblate sphere. So the top of Chimborazo is about 6,300 feet further out into Space than the top of Everest.Furthest from top to bottom: Mauna Kea is 33,500 ft. in height, much of it underwater.The bulkiest mountain that’s a defined peak: Mauna Loa, with a volume estimated at approximately 18,000 cubic miles (again, mostly underwater)And if we generously extend the definition of mountain to what is a massif, in this case a hybrid between a mid-ocean ridge and a shield volcano, by far the bulkiest land-form is Tamu Massif in the Pacific.Measures in imperial- I’ve converted to metric for everything except mountains, cooking and fish.

The largest mountain on Earth has never been climbed. It lurks in the dark and the deep. Bring up your mental picture of Italy: its highways, its cities, its slow roads and its Italian Alps. (If you’ve never been to Italy, think of Arizona, Finland, New Zealand, or Maharashtra — they’re all the right size).  [Image: Italian Alps] Now, take that mental picture, and imagine that the whole of Italy is one huge Alp. The sheer scale of it will try to slip away. Don’t let it. Hold that image in your head. That’s Earth’s largest mountain*. In 2013, a group of oceanographers in the Pacific discovered that the ridge they were studying was, in fact, one single volcano [ngeo1934]. They named it Tamu Massif. Here’s Tamu Massif, stretching 4,620m (14,633ft) above the seafloor. That’s a respectable height - about half the height of Mt. Everest - but the sheer size of it is extraordinary.  [Image: IODP] *I’m using the word “mountain” broadly here - Tamu Massif is underwater, barely explored, etc. I think this is a great starting point to debate the definition of “mountain”. I want this answer to prompt you to think about it - is Earth’s largest volcano too big to be a mountain? Too shallow? Too unfamiliar? For my own part, I think that discussing “Earth’s largest mountain” without mentioning Tamu Massif would be a bit like discussing “Earth’s biggest city” and saying that Tokyo is too sprawling out to count.
